body:
Yup, I, at least tried, it is doable:
    http://carreau.github.io/posts/05-YAML%20Notebook.html

Having json mean that we can compare the data structure we are using with what is in memory, and a space error in modifying a json file, will most likely raise an error than introduce a bad weird format hard to debug which can happend in yaml/.

YAML also suffer from "security feature" where you might be tempted to serialize an object in the store, which depends on the implementation (easy to slip), and json support across languages is more robust.
We ( by which I mean I) don't trust people to use `safe_load` and library author to make `load` == `safe_load` by default.

I know that yaml as some other advantages, like streaming and alike that might be usefull too,
but for know I think that the cost of yaml would be too high for interoperability vs the benefits.

Though we have pluggable backend, so you could do a yaml/reader writer, which woudl be nice to develop.

I'm going to close because there is nothing to "fix", but we can continue the discussion if you like.

Coming at this the other way, I don't think the purported benefits of YAML are especially useful here. We don't really expect people to read notebooks as plain text - whatever format you use, there's enough metadata there that it's going to be really awkward.

I have a script that flattens notebooks to make diffing better - see here:
https://gist.github.com/takluyver/bc8f3275c7d34abb68bf

Thanks for the quick comments.

Couple of quick followups:
- I wasn't suggesting new serialization capabilities (eg. object serialization), but rather just a different syntax for the same JSON data model. So I'd expect that to not result in new security surface area from new serialization approaches.
- Reading notebooks as plain text - I tend to think of this as quite interesting/mainline, certainly not fringe... conversion tools are fine if they're meant to be a one-way thing, but in scenarios like diff, you don't want to diff some derived output, but rather the notebook itself, if that is what you're committing in a changelist. I hear you that there is a bunch of metadata, but I think there is a lot more syntax noise, which would be eliminated with a more readable format.

Some of this is indeed opinion. I was curious about prior thought on this, so once again, thanks for the responses.

I know you were not suggesting the serialization capability, but if it's available, it would be (too) easy for a project to start using them, which would make the notebook incompatible.

The diff/merge-ability of the notebook are an issue, and we will be working on it, some things [have been done](http://nbdiff.org/) for that.
